prompt: What is a job hazard analysis?
options: A tallying of all the hazards found on the job
A technique that focuses on job tasks as a way to identify and correct hazards
A technique for analyzing job hazards and assigning them to appropriate categories
A technique for evaluating employees on the job to make sure they are working

prompt: When considering controls that protect a worker from on-the-job hazards, which type of control is the most important?
Employees who work on scaffolds must be protected from falling if the level of the scaffold is feet above the level below it.
In a personal fall arrest system, lanyards and vertical lifelines must have a minimum  breaking strength of:
Personal fall arrest systems, when stopping a fall, must be rigged so that no employee can free fall more than feet, nor contact any lower level.
When fall arrest equipment is used, employers must assure that:
options: Users have calculated total fall distance.
All equipment is properly inspected before each use.
A rescue plan is in place to rescue a fallen employee.

prompt: When is it necessary to use lockout/tagout procedures to prevent electrical injuries?
options: When anyone is working around electrical equipment
When anyone is working on equipment that has multiple energy sources
When two or more employees are performing maintenance on the same electrical equipment
When there is potential for an unexpected energization of equipment that could  cause injury to an employee

prompt: Ground Fault Circuit Interrupters (GFCI) are required by the National Electrical Code:
Who should be given access to electrical installations that are locked in a vault, room,  closet or fenced area?
options: Anyone with a legitimate reason for entering
Anyone who needs to work on the installation

prompt: When may guards be removed from powered equipment?
options: When something is stuck in it
When the equipment is off and locked out

prompt: Equipment such as cranes, forklifts, backhoes and scaffolding must maintain  at least a __________ foot minimum clearance from overhead power lines.
A stairway, ladder, ramp or other safe means of egress must be located in trench excavations that are or more in depth.
How far back from an excavation must the spoils be?
Excavations over 6 feet deep and not obviously visible must be, at minimum:
How often should vehicles being used at worksites be inspected?
options: Daily, at the beginning of each shift

prompt: To prevent worker run-over accidents, which of the following should be used?
Employees who direct or signal crane movements must be:
options: Able to also operate the crane.

prompt: Employees working from articulating boom lifts must:
options: Be tied off to the lift.
Be trained to operate the lift.
Keep their feet on the floor of the lift.

prompt: Which of the following is a sign of heat stress?
source: OSHA Heat Stress Quick Card (on Tools and Resources CD)

prompt: Which of the following is a sign of cold stress?
source: OSHA Cold Stress Quick Card (on Tools and Resources CD)
